awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of a Circular Dichroism Spectrometer for Research and Training of Undergraduate Students
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI), the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) as well as the Chemistry of Life Processes (CLP) programs, Professor Kumar Sinniah from Calvin College and colleagues David Benson, Douglas Vander Griend, Rachael Baker and Jiyan Ma have acquired a circular dichroism (CD) spectrometer. Many chemical and biological molecules are chiral (having structures that are not superimposable - like our hands). Chiral molecules that are prevalent in living organisms can exist in two forms. These can be described as having left-handed or right-handed conformations. A CD spectrometer can determine which form or whether a mixture of both is present. The spectrometer can follow changes as the chiral molecule binds to another molecule (ligand), rearranges its structure, or reacts (perhaps with a drug or an antibody).  Therefore, CD spectroscopy is ideally suitable for probing protein (or other macromolecular) structures or changes to structures due to environmental conditions or to the binding of a ligand. CD spectroscopy has been widely used for three types of measurements: identifying the structure of proteins, studying the conformational changes during folding and unfolding of proteins, and determining the energetics involved in binding interactions and protein unfolding. This spectrometer is used by undergraduates.  While being trained to use this important tool, the research experience prepares the students for future careers and advanced degrees in medical and scientific fields. 

This award is aimed at enhancing education and training of undergraduates and advancing research, especially in areas such as: (a) investigating the binding interaction between G-quadruplex DNA and insulin, (b) measuring the far ultra-violet and the near-infrared circular dichroism to understand the contribution of cysteine-tyrosine post-translational modifications on protein stability and function, (c) investigating the folding and unfolding thermodynamics of proteins and peptide systems, (d) investigating the functional role of Ras monoubiquitination, and (e) monitoring the folding, stability, and conformational conversion of various prion protein mutants.

por.por_cntn:
The circular dichroism (CD) spectrometer acquired at Calvin University was utilized for the research activities of 5 PIs (Dr. Kumar Sinniah, Dr. Dave Benson, Dr. Douglas Vander Griend, Dr. Rachael Baker, and Dr. Jiyan MA), undergraduate research students, and students in an upper-level biochemistry course.  

 

In Dr. Sinniah’s research, 3 undergraduate research students (Hannah Peterson, Elizabeth Peterson, Rachael Bouwman) were trained on the use of the CD spectrometer. CD results were obtained to determine the conformation of G-quadruplex structures at various temperatures.  While the CD results complemented the isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) results obtained for the same G-quadruplex DNA sequences, it also showed our interpretation of the binding of insulin to various forms of G-quadruplexes from the insulin-linked polymorphic region required a substantial revision of a manuscript and additional experiments.  Dr. Sinniah’s group also completed a study on the dominant sequence found in the insulin-linked polymorphic region (ILPR) as a function of the length of the sequence at temperatures ranging from 20-37 degrees Celsius.  The CD results showed while the binding of insulin to G-quadruplexes formed from various DNA lengths does not affect the topology of the G-quadruplex structures, it does have an effect on the structure of insulin.  These results were presented by an undergraduate student, Rachael Bouwman, at the West Michigan Undergraduate Research Symposium at Van Andel Institute in Grand Rapids, Michigan in the Fall of 2018.

 

Dr. Sinniah and Dr. Ma also collaborated to study the cardiolipin induced conformational changes of alpha-synuclein amyloid fibrils using the CD spectrometer.  The finding is intriguing, which shows that cardiolipin does interact with alpha-synuclein fibrils and to a certain extent, disaggregates the fibrils. Together with our recent finding that the pathogenic alpha-synuclein aggregates preferentially bind to mitochondria, the CD result may indicate that cardiolipin, a mitochondria-resident lipid, plays a role in modulating alpha-synuclein aggregates in Parkinson’s and other neurodegenerative diseases. One undergraduate student (Rachael Bouwman) worked fulltime on this project.

 

Dr. Vander Griend collected data from the CD titration experiments which were included in his NSF proposal submitted on October 31, 2019.  In the NSF proposal submitted, he proposed continuing work on tryptophan zippers (Trp-Zips) and their coordination chemistry using the CD spectrometer.

 

Dr. Benson reports that their group has not been able to obtain validated pure post-translationally modified protein to perform CD spectroscopy.  The crosslink between Cys 98 and Tyr 52 should change the chemical and thermal stability of the protein (BF4112). Most of their effort has been placed on revising an assay over the last two years as they discovered there is a major fluorescent contaminant in the guanidine stock used in their native fluorescence assay. Towards this end, they did not see a significant difference in CD thermal melts in BF4112 with and without some degree of post-translational modification. Dr. Benson’s group is currently synthesizing Cys-Tyr bispeptide using organometallic S-arylation methods for a HPLC standard that will be used in concert with 3 M HCl hydrolysis. Dr. Benson’s group is excited to use the CD spectrometer once pure Cys-Tyr BF4112 is validated for comparison to unmodified BF4112. 

Dr. Baker is currently studying a new AAA ATPase, BCS1L. As part of this new project, she is collaborating with a colleague at the University of Missouri to understand how various mutations alter the structure and activity of the protein. Once they have worked out the purification of the ATPase, they plan to use CD for the analysis of secondary structure and thermal stability when various disease-causing mutations are introduced into the protein. 

 

In addition to the aforementioned research activities, the CD spectrometer was also utilized for an upper-level biochemistry laboratory course at Calvin University, where 8 students per lab in three different sections were able to use the CD spectrometer to study the denaturation of lysozyme. Based on the success in using this instrument in a course, we plan to use the CD spectrometer in other upper-level laboratory courses.

 

The CD spectrometer we purchased is robust and has been relatively easy to train undergraduate students.  While Dr. Sinniah has continued to provide assistance and training for undergraduate students on the CD spectrometer, he will continue to do so with new students and new partners who require the use of the instrument.
